required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Spinal Sufentanil for Relief of Labor Pain in Primi- and Multiparous Parturients

brief_summary.textblock:
Background: This descriptive study was designed to evaluate effects and adverse effects of spinal sufentanil for relief of labor pain in primi- and multiparous women.
Methods: The retrospective study design was approved by the regional Human Research Ethics Review Board, Lund, Sweden (Dnr 2015/687). The investigators included 164 (82 primi- and 82 multiparous) obstetrical patients given 10 µg of intrathecal sufentanil for labor pain. Any maternal hypotension, third- or fourth-degree perineal tear, intrapartum Cesarean section, abnormal fetal heart rate, low Apgar score, use of neonatal intensive care, postdural puncture headache, epidural blood patch, and breastfeeding problem was recorded. Major outcome measures were maternal satisfaction with pain relief, and provision of supplementary analgesia.

detailed_description.textblock:
A total sample size of 150 parturients had been calculated to enable differences of at least 20 % versus 5.0 % in proportions of obstetrical and neonatal problems between (equal numbers of) primi- and multiparous mothers to be statistically confirmed with 80 % power and 95 % probability.
Descriptive parametric data is reported as mean ± standard deviation (SD), and proportions in percent with 95 % confidence interval (CI).
Parametric data was compared with two-tailed unpaired student's t-test, and proportions analyzed with Fisher's exact test.
Probability (P) values < 0.05 were considered statistically significant.

primary_outcome.time_frame: During the first 20 minutes after spinal analgesia with 5 minutes intervals
primary_outcome.description: Number of parturients with decrease in blood pressure by more than 30 % from the baseline level

primary_outcome.time_frame: During the first hour after spinal analgesia
primary_outcome.description: FHR(fetal heart rate)<100 beats/min for more than 90sec

primary_outcome.time_frame: During the first hour after spinal analgesia
primary_outcome.description: FHR(fetal heart rate)<100beats/min following a contraction
Number of parturients requiring supplementary spinal analgesia
Number of parturients requiring supplementary epidural analgesia
Number of parturients requiring instrumental delivery
Number of parturients requiring Cesarean section
Rate of third- or fourth-degree perineal tear
Number of parturients requiring oxytocin before spinal analgesia
Number of parturients requiring oxytocin after spinal analgesia
Number of parturients who are satisfied with pain relief
Number of parturients with postspinal dural puncture headache
Number of parturients requiring epidural blood patch

secondary_outcome.measure: Low Apgar score of newborn (Apgar score ≤ 7 )
secondary_outcome.time_frame: One minute and 5 minutes after birth
secondary_outcome.description: Number of newborns with Apgar score ≤ 7
Number of newborns requiring intensive care unit

arm_group.description: 82 primiparous obstetrical patients given intrathecal sufentanil for labor pain.
82 multiparous obstetrical patients given intrathecal sufentanil for labor pain.

intervention.description: Spinal analgesia (SA) was provided by a resident or specialist anaesthesiologist with the patient in a sitting or a recumbent position. A pencil-point needle, primarily 27 G (0.4 mm), otherwise 25 G (0.5 mm), was used for transdermal intrathecal administration of 2.0 ml of sufentanil 5 µg/ml (Sufenta®, Janssen-Cilag AB, Solna, Sweden) at low-lumbar level. Blood pressure was recorded before, immediately after, and at five-minute intervals for 20 minutes after the block. Any decrease in blood pressure by more than 30 % from the baseline level despite infusion of crystalloid was defined to indicate maternal hypotension.

study_pop.textblock: Primi- and multiparous obstetrical patients at the maternity ward of the Central Hospital in Kristianstad, Sweden, between 7th January 2013 and 29th July 2016

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Intrathecal sufentanil for labor pain
Exclusion Criteria:
Demographic, obstetrical or neonatal data is missing
